title: FAIR AI Ready Data Checklist
description: These checklists are developed by the Open Science Team at SciLifeLab Sweden, in collaboration with blabla

items.title: Create a Data Management Plan (DMP)
items.description: Before starting data collection, outline how data will be collected or produced, stored, maintained, shared, and preserved in a DMP that is continuously maintained throughout the project.

items.title: Document contextual metadata from the start
items.description: Maintain a README with descriptions of datasets (size, bias), variables (types, ranges), methods, and quality dimensions (completeness, bias, etc.).

items.title: Provide machine-readable metadata for discovery
items.description: Describe your data in a way that supports automatic indexing and searching. Include metadata such as content, author, persistent identifier (PID), collection period, subject area, and keywords. Metadata should be stored with the dataset and should remain accessible even if the data is restricted or removed.

items.title: Use a standard metadata schema
items.description: Apply a recognised metadata schema (e.g., [Dublin Core](https://www.dublincore.org/), [DataCite](https://schema.datacite.org/), or field-specific standards such as those managed by [EMBL-EBI](https://www.ebi.ac.uk/).

items.title: Share data in a repository that assigns a DOI
items.description: Deposit your data in a trusted repository with a persistent identifier (PID), e.g. DOI, to ensure long-term access and citation.  If the data can not be hosted fully openly due to security reasons, the procedure for accessing it should be described clearly. Review the Finding a suitable repository section of the RDM Guidelines to choose the repository type best suited to your data.

items.title: Include a data availability statement in your publication
items.description: Reference your data with a clear data availability statement, for example using the [template provided by AGU](https://www.agu.org/publications/authors/journals/data-software-for-authors#needed#availability-statement), so others can find, access, and reuse it. If access is restricted, specify who can access it and how to request access.

items.title: Use a self assessment checklist
items.description: Use a self assessment checklist  such as [ImmPorts AI-Readiness Assessment](https://doi.org/10.21430/qvk1-nn87) to make sure and communicate that you are following best practices.

items.title: Choose an appropriate open licence
items.description: Select a suitable licence for your data. The SciLifeLab standard for data and creative works (e.g. training materials, illustrations) is [CC BY 4.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/deed.en). Content without a licence cannot legally be reused, even if it is publicly available.

items.title: Use open machine-readable file formats
items.description: Use open machine-readable file formats for your resources (e.g., CSV, TXT, PNG, WAV), as opposed to proprietary formats (XLSX, PSD), so the permissions granted by your licence can be applied.

items.title: Include Example Use Cases
items.description: Include practical examples, like Jupyter notebooks, to illustrate how to work with the data.

items.title: Automate and share processing steps
items.description: Sharing only the data and its description may not be sufficient to explain how it was produced. Use notebooks, scripts, or workflow tools to automate and record data collection, processing, and analysis to ensure it is consistent, reproducible and traceable. Make relevant software, workflows, or code openly available alongside the data. See the [open software checklist](https://doi.org/10.17044/scilifelab.29086775) for guidance.

sources.title: The Turing Way: A handbook for reproducible, ethical and collaborative research
